title: The New Kid in Robotics Club

chapters.text: Jake stood frozen in the doorway of the robotics club, clutching his backpack straps so tightly his knuckles turned white. Twenty pairs of eyes stared back at him. The room buzzed with the sounds of small motors, clicking keyboards, and whispered conversations that stopped the moment he appeared. A tall girl with bright blue hair looked up from a half-assembled robot and waved him over. "Hey! You must be Jake. I'm Zoe." She pointed to an empty chair beside her. "We need someone who knows coding." Jake hesitated, remembering how his last school's popular kids had pretended to befriend him just to copy his science homework. But something about Zoe's smile seemed genuine. Maybe this time would be different. Maybe here, being smart wouldn't make him a target. He took a deep breath and stepped into the room, unaware that one of his new "friends" was already planning to use his skills for their own gain.

Jake moved cautiously toward an empty seat, feeling the weight of everyone's stares. The robotics club room buzzed with activity - half-built machines, scattered tools, and computer screens displaying complex diagrams. A tall boy with glasses approached him, introducing himself as Tyler. "We heard you won the state coding competition last year," Tyler said, his smile not quite reaching his eyes. Jake nodded shyly, setting his backpack down. Tyler patted his shoulder a bit too firmly and offered to show him around. As they walked between workstations, Tyler kept asking detailed questions about Jake's programming experience. "We could really use someone with your talents on our competition team," Tyler insisted, already imagining how Jake's skills could help him claim the glory he'd been chasing. Jake didn't notice the calculating look in Tyler's eyes as he eagerly explained the robot he'd built last summer.

Tyler nodded slowly, his fingers tapping against the metal workbench as Jake described the solar-powered arm that could pick up small objects. "That's pretty basic," Tyler said with a smirk, adjusting the shiny crown badge pinned to his robotics team jacket. "We built something like that in elementary school." A few students snickered behind their computer screens. Jake's smile faltered, but he continued showing the detailed sketches in his notebook. The robot might not be fancy, but he had designed and built it all by himself without any kits or help. Ms. Rodriguez, the club advisor, walked over and examined Jake's drawings. "I'm impressed with your independent work," she said loudly enough for everyone to hear. "We could use someone with your creative approach on our competition team." Tyler's smirk disappeared as Jake's confidence began to return.

Jake took a deep breath and stepped further into the room, his shoulders relaxing slightly. "I built a drone last summer that could follow motion patterns," he said, his voice growing stronger with each word. The other students' expressions changed from skepticism to interest. Even Tyler looked surprised. A girl with curly hair sitting near the front motioned to an empty chair beside her. "We need someone who knows about flight mechanics for our competition team," she explained. Jake nodded and made his way through the maze of robot parts and tools scattered across tables. As he sat down, he noticed a shiny blue HELMET on the shelf behind them, probably used for safety during testing. The robotics teacher, Mr. Chen, walked over with a friendly smile. "Welcome to the team, Jake. We're working on autonomous navigation today. Think you can help?"

Jake stood frozen in the doorway of the robotics club, clutching his backpack straps so tightly his knuckles turned white. Twenty pairs of eyes stared back at him. His heart pounded as the robotics teacher, Mr. Wilson, waved him in with a friendly smile. "Everyone, this is Jake, our newest member," Mr. Wilson announced. Jake shuffled forward, trying not to trip over the jumble of wires and robot parts scattered across the floor. A girl with curly hair scooted over, making space at her table. "I'm Mia," she said, showing him a small robot she was building. "Want to help?" Jake nodded, slowly releasing his grip on his backpack. He sat down beside Mia and picked up a screwdriver. The room buzzed with chatter and the whirring of small motors as Jake carefully attached a metal arm to Mia's robot, his nervousness beginning to fade.

The room buzzed with chatter and the whirring of small motors as Jake carefully attached a metal arm to Mia's robot, his nervousness beginning to fade. His fingers worked with surprising steadiness, connecting wires and tightening screws while Mia watched with an approving smile. The robot suddenly beeped to life, its metal arm rotating smoothly in a perfect circle. "You're really good at this," Mia said, high-fiving Jake as other club members gathered around to see their creation. Jake felt his face grow warm at the attention, but for the first time since entering the robotics club, he didn't want to disappear. Mr. Wilson, the club sponsor, walked over and examined their work. "Excellent joint mechanism," he noted, patting Jake's shoulder. "We could use skills like yours for the state competition next month." Jake nodded, already imagining improvements for their robot's design.

Jake nodded, already imagining improvements for their robot's design. He pulled out his notebook and sketched a new arm mechanism that would give their machine better precision. The other club members gathered around, their earlier stares now filled with interest instead of judgment. "This could work," said Mia, the team captain. Over the next few weeks, Jake became an essential part of the robotics club. His design helped their robot win the regional competition, earning them a spot at nationals. On the bus ride home, surrounded by his cheering teammates and their shiny trophy, Jake smiled. The robot sat in its protective case, decorated with team stickers and signatures. What had started as the scariest moment of his school year had turned into the best decision he'd ever made. Jake wasn't the new kid anymoreâ€”he was just part of the team.
